happening/instance/reason/cause/intentional/former/old/friend/therefore/hence/(of people) to die, dead
lane/alley

sentences.english: No educated guesses' about what to do or chart reading.
sentences.chinese: 没有故弄玄虚的猜测和图表统计分析。

sentences.english: It will be my pleasure to share with you some of this double-talk so typical of our times.
sentences.chinese: 我很乐意摘录几则典型的故弄玄虚的评论，与君共享。

sentences.english: However, the audience will feel that the story is too hypocritical, director mystify .
sentences.chinese: 不过，也会有观众觉得故事太矫情，导演故弄玄虚。

sentences.english: On some level this definition may seem like quite a lot of scientific mumbo-jumbo.
sentences.chinese: 在某种程度上，这一定义可能显得有点故弄玄虚。

sentences.english: I want to be deliberately mystifying in here neither, he does not have but courage.
sentences.chinese: 我也不想在这里故弄玄虚，可是他没有勇气。

definition: lit. dress up as God, play the devil (idiom); fig. to mystify/to deceive people/to scam
posturing/pretentious/affected
to put on an act
sensationalism/vulgar claptrap to please the crowds/playing to the gallery/demagogy
deceitful trick/mystery/unfathomable
to show off/to make a display of
apparently right but actually wrong; specious (idiom)
to play the profound thinker
to make things up/to concoct (a story, an excuse etc)
to concoct a cock-and-bull story (idiom)/to make things up
profound mystery
to fool the world and usurp a good name (idiom)
trying to hide it makes it more conspicuous (idiom); A cover up only makes matters worse.
to invent crazy nonsense/to cook up (excuses)/to talk at random/wild babble
to speak without thinking (idiom)/to blurt sth out
to make an irrelevant comparison or interpretation (idiom)
